 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed senior 
secured debt financing of up to $150,000,000 (in Indian rupee equivalent) to Fullerton India Credit 
Company Limited (FICC) for the Expanding Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Lending 
Project in India. 
 
2. 
The debt financing will support the growth of FICC’s financing portfolio for micro, small, 
and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs), providing needed financial products and services to this 
underserved segment. At least 50% of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) facility will be for loans 
in lagging states.1 As a result of the ADB intervention, FICC will also implement a gender action 
plan (GAP) to expand its lending to women-led MSMEs in India. At least 60% of the ADB facility 
will finance loans to women MSME borrowers.2 
 

II. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 

Investment Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises sector. Based on the findings of the 2018 
report of the International Finance Corporation (IFC) on the MSME sector in India, the country 
had an estimated 55.8 million (nonagricultural) MSMEs in fiscal year (FY) 2017, operating (top 5 
industries) in retail (46.0%), food products and beverages (6.0%), apparel (5.0%), motor vehicle 
repair  (4.0%),  and  textiles  (3.0%).3  Predominately  unregistered,  94.9%  of  MSMEs  were 
microenterprises,  4.9%  were  small  enterprises,  and  0.2%  were  medium-sized  enterprises.4 
MSMEs  accounted  for  about  31%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  and  45%  of  exports,  and 
employed  more  than  124  million  people.  Approximately  59.5%  of  MSMEs  are  located  in  rural 
areas and 40.5% are in urban areas. For MSMEs the lack of adequate access to finance is seen 
as a major obstacle to growth, with 84% of all MSMEs self-financing or using informal finance 
sources and only 16% of MSMEs accessing credit from formal financial institutions. The lack of 
readily accessible finance is even more acute for women-led MSMEs. 
 
4. 
Women in the micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises sector. MSMEs owned by 
women  accounted  for  14.0%–20.4%  of  all  MSMEs  in  FY2017.5  Based  on  a  2014  IFC  study, 
approximately 78% of enterprises owned by women are in the services sector.6 For this and other 
reasons,  women  entrepreneurship  is  largely  skewed  toward  smaller  firms,  with  almost  98%  of 
businesses owned by women categorized as microenterprises. Low levels of women-ownership 
of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are common in many countries in the region. In 
South Asia, only 9% of SMEs are owned by women.7 Access to formal finance is one key barrier

being met through informal sources. The financing gap for women-owned MSMEs totaled ₹6.37 
trillion  or  roughly  73%  of  total  demand  in  FY2012.  Women  have  more  difficulties  than  men  in 
accessing  credit  for  a  variety  of  reasons,  including  limited  awareness  and  understanding  of 
financial products because of their lack of financial education and unfamiliarity with formal banking 
institutions, lack of collateral to guarantee credit, difficulty in presenting their personal profiles and 
track records, the requirement for support from male family members for loan applications, and 
other discriminatory practices by loan officers (footnote 7). In recognition of the difficulties faced 
by MSMEs, particularly those owned by women, the Government of India has launched several 
initiatives  designed  to  achieve  greater  participation  of  women  in  the  sector  and  enhance 
enterprise growth.8 
 
Rationale. Notwithstanding the size of the financial sector and the significant strides the 
5. 
government is making in its financial inclusion strategy, access to finance in India remains a key 
issue,  with  fewer  than  7%  of  adults  accessing  loans  through  formal  channels.9  In  rural  areas, 
access to finance is even more scarce, with only 5% of rural residents reporting having borrowed 
to start, operate, or expand a business (footnote 3). The 2018 IFC report on India’s MSME sector 
identified MSMEs’ lack of adequate access to finance as the biggest challenge to further growth 
and underlies the reason why most micro and small enterprises do not graduate to become formal 
job-making  SMEs  (footnote  3).  Banks  have  typically  limited  exposure  to MSMEs  because  of  a 
higher risk perception and MSMEs’ limited access to immovable collateral. Given the continued 
need to address credit access issues and to support the government’s financial inclusion efforts, 
ADB  has  identified  financial  institution  partners  that  have  demonstrated  the  ability  to  reach 
underbanked segments on  a profitable and sustainable basis  and support the  development  of 
India’s  “missing  middle”  –  SMEs  and  the  lower  middle-income  segment  –  through  their 
involvement with MSMEs. One such institution is FICC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Fullerton 
Financial Holdings (FFH). Incorporated as a nonbank finance institution (NBFI) in India in 2005, 
FICC  targets  the  lower-income  and  emerging  middle-income  segments,  providing  MSME 
business  credit  in  rural  and  urban  India.  Over  the  past  several  years,  FICC  has  become  an 
important institution in the market, with total assets under management (AUM) of ₹194.7 billion 
as of the end of the first 9 months of FY2019 (9MFY2019). Present across 22 states and 3 union 
territories, FICC has 616 branches that cover more than 600 towns and 55,000 villages, staffed 
by over 13,600 employees who serve 3 million customers. 
 
B. 
 
Overview. FICC has established a core market niche serving the customer segment with 
6. 
an income range that is below the level traditionally targeted by banks and above the level served 
by microfinance institutions. FICC estimates that nearly 75 million households in India fall within 
this  category,  comprised  of  self-employed  and  salaried  individuals  with  incomes  that  range 
between  ₹200,000–₹450,000  per  annum  (approximately  $2,800–$6,400)  in  rural  areas  and 
₹450,000–₹1.1 million (approximately $6,400-$15,800) in urban areas. To address the unmet and 
underserved needs of this segment for tailored financial services, FICC has adopted differentiated 
rural  (includes  semi-urban)  and  urban  strategies  to  engage  efficiently  across  the  customers’ 
business and income growth life cycles, with deliberate and distinct product and strategy mixes. 
FICC’s  rural  business  products  are  marketed  under  the  Gramshakti  brand  and  include  group

Business  strategy.  FICC  seeks  to  build  on  its  market  position  as  a  financial  services 
7. 
company  focused  on  MSMEs  and  other  underserved  low-income  segments  and  scale  its 
operations  across  India.  Specific  plans  include  expanding  its  branch  network  from  616  as  of 
9MFY2019 to 790 as of fiscal year end (FYE) 2021, opening most of these new branches in rural 
areas, in line with the demand–supply dynamics of the market. During this period, FICC targets 
increasing the contribution of rural segment loans from 33% to 40% of the portfolio. Beyond its 
geographical expansion, the company also aims to expand its product portfolio in new secured 
business  segments,  such  as  consumer  durable  loans,  dairy  loans,  and  loans  against  shares. 
Complementing the “high touch” aspects of FICC’s business strategy is the use of high-tech digital 
technology. FICC has invested considerably in the development of its digital technology platform 
to leverage multichannel availability of lending solutions. FICC also uses digital tools to assist in 
its business decision-making process, including using analytics to better target clients, automating 
part  of  the  credit  approval  process,  managing  return  volatility,  identifying  early  indications  of 
stress, and guiding deployment of collection resources based on score cards. In time, FICC seeks 
to  provide  a  fully  digitized  onboarding  process,  starting  from  biometric-enabled  know-your-
customer  forms  to  digitally  accepted  electronic  agreements,  using  geo-location  and  electronic 
data validation  of  application information,  and  finally  to  online  platforms for  customer  servicing 
through web- and mobile-based self-service. This will be complemented by mobile wallets and 
online payment platforms to improve the effectiveness of collections processes. 
 
C. 
 
8. 
Ownership. FICC is a wholly owned subsidiary of FFH. FFH has 4.31% direct ownership 
of FICC, while the remaining 95.69% is indirectly held through Angelica Investments Pte. Ltd., a 
Singapore-based  asset  management  company  and  a  wholly  owned  subsidiary  of  FFH. 
Established in 2003, FFH is a long-term strategic and operating investor in financial and related 
services  in  emerging  markets  throughout  Asia.  FFH  is  wholly  owned  by  Temasek  Holdings 
(Private)  Limited,  a  Singapore-based  global  investment  company.  FFH  provides  financial 
products and services to the lower-income and emerging middle-class customer segments, and 
MSMEs through  its  various  holdings  across the region.  Integrity  due  diligence  was  conducted, 
and no significant or potentially significant integrity risks were found.11 The beneficial owners do 
not appear to constitute a significant or potentially significant integrity risk, in the absence of any 
unresolved or substantiated adverse media or other information related to the individuals.12 
 
9. 
Corporate governance. FICC has a robust and experienced board of directors, following 
the regulatory requirements of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and the Securities and Exchange 
Board of India, the country’s capital markets regulator. The nine-member board is comprised of 
five independent directors with expertise in the financial services industry, FFH’s chief executive 
officer (CEO), FICC’s managing director, and two nonexecutive directors representing FFH. The 
board’s  committee  structure  includes  the  audit,  risk  oversight,  nomination  and  remuneration, 
corporate  social  responsibility,  and  information  technology  strategy  committees,  as  well  as  a

10.  Management.  FICC  has  a  highly  experienced  management  team  led  by  managing 
director  and  CEO  Ms.  Rajashree  Nambiar.  The  former  CEO  and  executive  director  of  India 
Infoline Finance Ltd. (the NBFI arm of the IIFL Group), Ms. Nambiar has more than 25 years of 
banking  and  financial  sector  experience.  FICC’s  senior  management  team  has  more  than  15 
years’  experience  on  average  and  a  strong  track  record  of  leading  business  units  in  their 
respective  segments  at  various  international  and  domestic  banks  as  well  as  at  other  large 
corporations. FICC also benefits from the strong support of its parent company, FFH, in terms of 
technical  expertise.  The  senior  management  team  from  FFH  regularly  participates  in  FICC’s 
monthly asset–liability and credit risk reviews through designated committees and continuously 
provides support and guidance. 
 
11. 
Risk management. FICC has a well-defined risk appetite framework that is approved by 
the  board  of  directors.  The  risk  framework  sets  defined  risk  limits  for  each  credit,  liquidity, 
operational, and reputational risk to balance returns and earnings targets with core financial needs 
for  solvency  and  volatility  management.  In  terms  of  organizational  structure,  FICC’s  chief  risk 
officer  reports  directly  to  the  board  of  directors  and  to  the  board  of  director’s  risk  oversight 
committee on a quarterly basis at a minimum. The four-member board risk oversight committee 
maintains  responsibility  for  oversight  and  monitoring  of  the  company’s  risk  framework,  with 
program approval directly reviewed by FFH’s risk management team.

C. 
 
17. 
Provide  access  to  longer  tenor  debt.  The  proposed  transaction  will  support  FICC’s 
growth  as  it  further  builds  its  presence  in  rural  areas  and  provides  increasing  access  to 
underserved  clients  in  India’s  lagging  states.  ADB’s  longer  -term  debt  financing  will  provide 
needed resources to help FICC manage its longer-term loans in both rural and urban areas as 
the  company  expands  its  secured  and  unsecured  MSME  business  loan  portfolios.  ADB’s 
proposed loan facility will also support FICC’s efforts to narrow the asset–liability management 
gap in its 3–5-year and greater than 5 years duration buckets where local markets are unable to 
provide  reasonable funding  sources.  FICC  estimates that  it  will  need  ₹75  billion  per  annum  of 
additional  debt  funding  during  FY2019–FY2021  to meet  its  overall  growth  targets.  ADB’s  debt 
financing  of  up  to  $150  million  (in  Indian  rupee  equivalent)  will  support  FICC’s  longer  tenor 
financing and would be equivalent to 10% of this requirement for the next 12 months. 
 
18. 
Support  the  growth  of  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and  the 
development  of  the  missing  middle.  ADB  funding  will  support  the  growth  of  FICC’s  MSME 
financing portfolio, helping improve access to finance for the missing middle, specifically targeting 
the  female  missing-middle,  and  providing  needed  financial  products  and  services  to  this 
underserved  segment.  In  addition  to  providing  MSMEs—many  of  which  are  in  rural  areas  or 
lagging  states  and/or  women-led—with  access  to  finance  for  working  capital  and  investment 
needs, this transaction will promote entrepreneurship and contribute to enterprise development. 
 
19. 
Support Fullerton India Credit Company’s gender action plan to increase access to 
finance  for  women-led  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises.  The  full  potential  of 
women-led MSMEs is constrained by their limited access to finance and the credit needed to start 
and grow their businesses (para. 4). The situation is further compounded by the limited awareness 
and understanding of financial products by many women-led MSMEs, the lack of experience with 
banking institutions; the lack of collateral with which to guarantee credit; and the requirement, in 
many instances, of having a male family member cosign the loan application (footnote 6). FICC’s 
total loan portfolio will more than double over the next 5 years; however, growth of the women 
MSME loan portfolio will increase by  only 1.5 times because of the aforementioned issues, as 
well as the challenges of outreach to women clients, especially in rural areas and lagging states 
(footnote 6). It is important to note, however, that FICC targets more than 60% of its borrowers to 
be women, well above the national baseline in which only 5% of women borrowed from a formal 
financial institution in 2017. Therefore, ADB’s funding of FICC will contribute to reducing gender 

5 

 

 6 

financing gaps. The size of a business can affect its capacity to access higher levels of credit. 
Since most women’s businesses are microenterprises and men’s businesses tend to be small or 
medium-sized,  the  average  size of  loans to  female borrowers  is  also  significantly  smaller than 
that to male borrowers. The GAP developed through this transaction, especially the use of tools 
to target women borrowers and lagging regions, as well as the development of gender-inclusive 
financial products, will strengthen and expand FICC’s effort to provide financial services to women 
entrepreneurs and contribute to the objective of increasing the participation of women-led MSMEs 
in the sector. This will be complemented by new activities committed to by FICC as part of this 
project to provide women with relevant financial and digital literacy skills, access to leadership 
positions, and opportunities for young women to acquire new skills and employment.

Outcomes. The project will sustainably expand FICC’s lending activities to MSMEs. 

 
A. 
 
20. 
Impact.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  access  to  finance  for  the 
underserved enhanced in alignment with the Government of India’s financial inclusion agenda, 
which  highlights  the  delivery  of  affordable  banking  and  other  financial  services  to  unserved  or 
underserved  groups  as  a  means  to  promote  poverty  reduction  and  inclusive  growth  through 
employment generation.13

environmental and social impacts of the proposed investments and associated risks have been 
assessed, as well as the company’s commitment to and capacity for environmental and social 
management. FICC will not use the proceeds of ADB’s funding to finance projects with category

peoples. FICC will apply ADB’s prohibited investment activities list, ensure that investments using

management  system  includes  arrangements  to  comply  with  national  labor  laws,  ADB’s  Social 
Protection Strategy (2001), and internationally recognized core labor standards. Since the project 
involves the financing of MSMEs with ADB proceeds, it will have very limited direct climate change 
impact.  
 
26. 
Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development, 
FICC  will  commit  to  incorporating  measures  to  promote  gender  equality  and  women’s 
empowerment in its business activities. Key features of the GAP proposed by ADB include targets 
to (i) increase access of women-led MSMEs to FICC’s loan products, customized to address the 
needs of women borrowers; (ii) increase  the number of women employees in FICC as well as 
women representation in branches and senior management; (iii) improve the competency of FICC 
employees to deliver services responsive to the needs of women borrowers; and (iv) strengthen 
its corporate social responsibility program by targeting women beneficiaries and introduce new 
women-focused initiatives that enhance the skills of women on computer literacy, online business, 
and entrepreneurship. FICC will submit periodic reports on implementation of gender measures 
to ADB.
